_exec_summary.SummaryText:
TrueCore's RMP-covered process consists of infrastructure, equipment, devices, and auxiliary support systems, all of which make up its foam panel manufacturing process.  Specifically, the insulative foam implanted within the panels is known as polyurethane foam.  Polyurethane foam is one of the most efficient insulating materials available on the market today. The foam's insulating abilities are due to the fact that the material is composed of solid foam cells that encapsulate vapor/gas. The foam cells are completely closed, which means that the vapor cannot escape, as well as that air and moisture are unable to infiltrate. 



TrueCore's covered chemical is a blend of Cyclopentane and Isopentane known as CP-80 - the mixture is composed of 80% Cyclopentane and 20% Isopentane, by weight.  CP-80 is used as a "blowing agent". A blowing agent is defined as a chemical that is capable of producing a cellular structure via a foaming process in which material(s) undergo hardening and/or other phase transition; blowing agents are generally applied when the blown material is still in a liquid stage.  The other two primary chemicals that are used in the polyurethane foam manufacturing process are polyether polyol and isocyanate.  When these ingredients are injected into a cavity, a chemical reaction occurs, which produces insulative foam material.  This foam will rapidly expand until it fills the cavity shell - the time for this reaction to completely occur necessarily varies based on the size of the cavity and exact blend of chemicals. As the foam solidifies, it closes, hardens, and becomes impermeable at the cellular level, trapping Cyclopentane/Isopentane and carbon dioxide vapor inside those cells. The complete reaction, which is known as polymerization, typically lasts about 2-5 minutes. The chemical reaction that takes place is irreversible and its component gases are permanently trapped with the now solid foam material.



The covered foam manufacturing process includes

ressure condition

- Safety programmable logic control (PLC) for process  - computerized and automatic monitoring, process control, and response has been implemented - the safety PLC will monitor numerous parameters (such as pressure, temperature, level, etc.) throughout all portions of the process; the PLC will also respond to potentially dangerous or harmful detections by modifying the process and/or isolating the equipment to a safe state until the problem can be identified and remedied

- Dedicated electrical grounding systems - dedicated grounding at the bulk chemical storage AST via a grounding reel that must be connected to the chemical delivery tanker; the grounding system is interlocked to require a successful ground between the tanker and AST before allowing for the operation of the static chemical unloading pump; the foaming process line is also provided dedicated grounding systems

- Electrically classified (XP/IS) equipment in areas that could be exposed to flammable vapors during routine or non-routine operations; this ensures that the equipment will be unable to introduce an electrical spark to a potentially hazardous concentration of flammable vapor

- Dedicated, discrete, and redundant exhaust ventilation systems for the metering unit and at the foaming process line; this will operate continuously when the line is active, has the ability to increase exhaust flow if a detection of flammable vapor is identified, and has redundancy built-in to make sure that exhausting ability is not lost if the primary fan motor fails

- Flammable vapor detection, monitoring, and alarm system to notify personnel of the presence of flammable vapor in the vicinity; this will also be monitored and controlled by the safety PLC such that additional ventilation measures can be implemented when vapor is detected and even so far as to isolate process equipment to make absolutely sure the process remains in a safe state

- Fire detection, suppression, and control throughout th

e building; this includes a dedicated standpipe and sprinkler systems installed strategically throughout the building.

- Uninterruptible power supply (UPS) battery backup for critical safety equipment and functionality - this will provide critical electrical supply and enable the PLC to maintain functionality in the event of a loss of electrical power at the site; the safety PLC will isolate the process and equipment and shut the system down to a safe state until electrical power is restored

- Lightning protection for the building - air terminals are mounted across the roof of the building, which are connected to subsurface down conductors that will safely transmit the lightning's electrical charge away from the building and sensitive equipment and devices, instead dissipating the charge safely into the ground.
